video.title: TensorFlow 2.0 Complete Course - Python Neural Networks for Beginners Tutorial
video.description:
Learn how to use TensorFlow 2.0 in this full tutorial course for beginners. This course is designed for Python programmers looking to enhance their knowledge and skills in machine learning and artificial intelligence. 

Throughout the 8 modules in this course you will learn about fundamental concepts and methods in ML & AI like core learning algorithms, deep learning with neural networks, computer vision with convolutional neural networks, natural language processing with recurrent neural networks, and reinforcement learning.

Each of these modules include in-depth explanations and a variety of different coding examples. After completing this course you will have a thorough knowledge of the core techniques in machine learning and AI and have the skills necessary to apply these techniques to your own data-sets and unique problems.


⭐️ Google Colaboratory Notebooks ⭐️

📕 Module 2: Introduction to TensorFlow - https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1F_EWVKa8rbMXi3_fG0w7AtcscFq7Hi7B#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true
📗 Module 3: Core Learning Algorithms - https://colab.research.google.com/drive/15Cyy2H7nT40sGR7TBN5wBvgTd57mVKay#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true
📘 Module 4: Neural Networks with TensorFlow - https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1m2cg3D1x3j5vrFc-Cu0gMvc48gWyCOuG#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true
📙 Module 5: Deep Computer Vision - https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1ZZXnCjFEOkp_KdNcNabd14yok0BAIuwS#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true
📔 Module 6: Natural Language Processing with RNNs -  https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1ysEKrw_LE2jMndo1snrZUh5w87LQsCxk#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true
📒 Module 7: Reinforcement Learning -  https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1IlrlS3bB8t1Gd5Pogol4MIwUxlAjhWOQ#forceEdit=true&sandboxMode=true


⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

⌨️ (00:03:25) Module 1: Machine Learning Fundamentals 
⌨️ (00:30:08) Module 2: Introduction to TensorFlow
⌨️ (01:00:00) Module 3: Core Learning Algorithms
⌨️ (02:45:39) Module 4: Neural Networks with TensorFlow
⌨️ (03:43:10) Module 5: Deep Computer Vision - Convolutional Neural Networks
⌨️ (04:40:44) Module 6: Natural Language Processing with RNNs
⌨️ (06:08:00) Module 7: Reinforcement Learning with Q-Learning
⌨️ (06:48:24) Module 8: Conclusion and Next Steps


⭐️ About the Author ⭐️

The author of this course is Tim Ruscica, otherwise known as “Tech With Tim” from his educational programming YouTube channel. Tim has a passion for teaching and loves to teach about the world of machine learning and artificial intelligence. Learn more about Tim from the links below:

topLevelComment.author: NotALlama
topLevelComment.text:
3:34:05 He's actually made a bit of a mistake here.  I've been watching a few other TensorFlow tutorials, and one thing I learned is that when you rerun the model.fit() method without completely redefining the model from step 0, you're actually just continuing the training from where you left off.  In other words, when he drops the epochs to 8, he's not training a new network with fewer epochs, he's training the same network he just trained _again,_ with 8 additional epochs.  You can actually see this in the output: the first epoch in the 10 epoch run has an accuracy of 0.8269, but the first epoch in the 8 epoch run starts above 0.9, as does the single epoch run.  By the end, the model has effectively gone through 19 epochs.

Tl;dr: he's not actually reducing the number of epochs like he thinks he his.  He's actually increasing it.

topLevelComment.author: NotALlama
topLevelComment.text: 1:08:21 I don't think that explanation of line of best fit is quite right.  I'm fairly certain actual algorithms don't care about splitting the points evenly, they just look for the line that minimizes the sum of the distances to each point.  Sometimes that splits them evenly, but not always.  For example, lets say you have a dataset that consists of a number of points that are fairly close together, but a few that are quite far away (of course, they would have to be close enough to not be outlier data).  The line of best fit would try to minimize the distance to _all_ points, including the few farther ones, and that might not necessarily split the data points evenly.

topLevelComment.author: Aalap Shah
topLevelComment.text:
3:00:00 [Errata] Sum i=0 to n is erroneous. n being number of features, it should either be i=1 to n or i=0 to n-1, depending on whether you use a 0 or 1 based indexing.
3:37:00 [Terminology] When testing accuracy was better at epoch=1 than at epoch=10; what using a smaller epoch (data pass) is called early stopping - a method of regularization, i.e. reduce overfitting.
4:20:00 [Errata] With TensorFlow v2.0, keras is part of TensorFlow, and is recommended to not be installed separately. The import statement should be 'from tensorflow.keras.…'
4:23:00 [Terminology] Using an existing model and modifying and/or adding just last (aka top) few layers is called Transfer Learning.
4:27:00 [Clarification] format_example seems to be doing 2 things: reduce image size, and scale RGB values from [0, 255] to [-1, 1] (instead of the typical scale of 0-1). This is most likely a requirement of the MobileNet model that is being used as a base later on, it has been trained on input within this scale. Also, I don't think you collapsed the 3 channels of RGB into a single channel of Gray, so cmap on RGB has no effect. I believe the colors are darker, because the new image RGB channels are now between [-1.0, 1.0] (float), and plt.imgshow() has considered all negative numbers as 0, effectively making the image [0.0, 1.0] (float) and multiplied each number by 255. Efffectively, all pixels that originally had low RGB values became black, and the ones that had high RGB values (were brighter), got collapsed to between [0, 127], i.e. became darker.

topLevelComment.author: Mr. Fahrenheit
topLevelComment.text: I think it's clear that the brain strongly inspired artificial neural networks. A biological neuron receives  information through synaptic connections to adjacent neurons. If that neuron is stimulated past a certain threshold, it's said to be "activated," and it fires its own signal that is then transmitted to other adjacent neurons to interact with. That's where we got the idea to divide and conquer the data in a layered-like fashion, activation, bias (threshold), and a weighted sum (representing the connections)

topLevelComment.author: Dr. Mikey Bee
topLevelComment.text: Nice lesson.  You keep the topics simple and easy to follow.  Very few data scientists do that.  BTW, I like to think of a graph as a factory.  It sits there waiting to transform input, whereas eager execution is like a bespoke artisanal shop. It performs primitive steps one after the other for every batch.  It's like recasting molds for every bag of plaster.  If you have a lot of data to process, the graph method is more efficient.

topLevelComment.author: Academic library
topLevelComment.text:
Learn how to use TensorFlow 2.0 in this full tutorial course for beginners. This course is designed for Python programmers looking to enhance their knowledge and skills in machine learning and artificial intelligence. 

Throughout the 8 modules in this course you will learn about fundamental concepts and methods in ML & AI like core learning algorithms, deep learning with neural networks, computer vision with convolutional neural networks, natural language processing with recurrent neural networks, and reinforcement learning.

Each of these modules include in-depth explanations and a variety of different coding examples. After completing this course you will have a thorough knowledge of the core techniques in machine learning and AI and have the skills necessary to apply these techniques to your own data-sets and unique problems.

topLevelComment.author: Marcel De Sutter
topLevelComment.text:
Although I can appreciate the amount of content in this video, I must point out for the beginners here that some of the explanations in the video are not correct. I am currently at 2:03:08 and so far I have noticed two main things:

at 1:11:05 he explained that in linear regression in 3d space, assuming a linear relationship, you try to use two variables to predict the value of the third. This is true, but the model is then not a straight line pointing somewhere in 3d space, but a 2d plane. Such false information gives beginners a bad intuition for these things. 

Furthermore, the whole Titanic survival prediction section was a classification task, so it had little to do with linear regression. He used the LinearClassifier object, which (probably) runs a logistic regression in the background. In the output dictionary, there were keys that are typical for the output of a logistic regression. Although linear regression and logistic regression are both algorithms that create models that assume a linear relationship between input variables, they are completely different algorithms. I would have liked to see a clear distinction between regression and classification problems here, because these are fundamental concepts in ML and the video wrongly conveys that you solve a regression problem by predicting whether a passenger survives or not.

edit: His intuitive explanation at 3:09:13 of what activation functions do is just wrong. The sigmoid function does not project the data points into higher dimensional space, quite the opposite, actually. The sigmoid function is defined as f: R^n -> [0,1], so it takes as input an n-dimensional vector and it yields a scalar (fancy word for a single number). This whole "projection into higher dimensional space" thing is known as the Kernel trick and is NOT used in his examples, it's something completely different. Activation functions are used in Neural Networks because they introduce non-linearity which you need because otherwise your Neural Network would just be a linear classifier so it would basically do one big weighted summation of the inputs. This is not enough to capture complicated relationships in data. With non-linearity introduced, it can be shown that a Neural Network can approximate any function with arbitrary accuracy, that is any function that might have generated the data. Read up on the universal approximation theorem, if you want to learn more.

edit 2: 3:36:15 You don't evaluate on your test data multiple times to select the best set of hyperparameters. That way, you overfit your test data. A cleaner approach would be to split the data into three sets: the training set, the validation set and the test set. Prior to training you define a few selections of hyperparameters you want to select the best from before you train all these models on the training data. You then evaluate the performance of each model on the validation data. Finally, you select the best performing model and test it on the test data to get a final estimate of the model's performance on completely new data points. There are more sophisticated approaches to do hyperparameter tuning but this is the basic idea.

topLevelComment.author: Dani Lerner
topLevelComment.text: Okay I'm not completely sure about this so take it with a grain of salt but I don't think you're hyperparameter/epoch tuning at 3:37:00 is doing what you expect. With jupyter notebooks, it saves the models and each time you run an epoch, it continues tuning the previous weights. In order to really display epoch differences, you need to restart the runtime and repeat the process. If you notice, each time you run the code, the "first epoch accuracy" increases significantly. The first time you ran it, the accuracy was 83% after the first epoch. After the 10th, it was 90.6%. Then, for the next iteration (8 epochs), the accuracy was 91.2% after the first epoch. Then, when running on just a single epoch, it started at 93%. Likely this is because the model continued to train an additional 9 epochs. So, in fact, the single epoch data is ironically quite overfitting.

replies.author: Kavana V Vasishta
replies.text: Hey. That is because the weights of the kernels of the pre-trained model essentially capture the features of an image, in general; i.e, edges, eye shape, contrast, hair color, etc. Also, these weights will be close to accurate as the model would have been trained on a huge amount of data set with many epochs. This is the reason you can use somebody else's pre-trained model as a base model on which you can build your own classification model. Hope the answer helps.

i have high regards for Tim, Titanic is a classification problem not regression. im sure even an intermediate level Machine Learning Programmer knows this that for specific number of outputs or discrete output (1 and 0 in this case) classification is used and regression is used for prediction for continuous variables  like to predict price of house. Tim didnt even mention the term classification and he even used LinearClassifier which is probably used for classification as name implies. really in doubt how an ML expert like Tim would forget such a fundamental thing .


That really sets bad intuition for beginners and they would get confused when they get to know what both of these terms actually mean.

thats enough to decide that this video is not a video to watch especially for beginners. 
Tim is an awesome dude, i have learned a lot from him but this is just not the video i would recommend anyone to watch.

i hope Tim acknowledges this

STANDARD DEVIATION: When we find the average of all the points, then it is called mean. And from the mean point, all the other points may deviate by some degrees. If we find all the deviations of the points from the mean, and average it, we get standard deviation.
For mean temperature 15 and standard deviation 10 means, that throughout the day the temperature varied. But if we find the average of the temperature throughout the day, its mean is 15. The variation can be min:-15 to max:+50, that does not matter, but if we find the average of the variation from the mean then we get a standard deviation 10.

topLevelComment.author: Alisson Damasceno
topLevelComment.text:
Just a comment, on 3:36:44, when you train the network again it's not re-training from scratch but instead using the weights it already had. Unless you manually reset the graph, you'll be training for the sum of all epochs you used the fit function (like 10 + 8 + 1 epochs)
To avoid this problem you should use something like keras.backend.clear_session() or tf.reset_default_graph() between tests with hyperparameters 😉

replies.author: Sangramjit Chakraborty
replies.text: Best bet for time series data is using an RNN. It's not hard. It's just a layer inside a for loop, and some state which is preserved across each iteration. The iterations are called the timesteps. You can simply use the Keras SimpleRNN, GRU or LSTM layers, so that you don't have to write the timestep loop yourself.

topLevelComment.author: shinunotenshi
topLevelComment.text: Sadly, the questions nobody really answers weren't answered here either: How does one decide which activation functions to pick? What problems require which kind of activation functions? Also, how do you go about deciding how big your layers are? You and everyone else says it depends, but on what? Are these all questions answered by hyper-parameter tuning, or is there more wisdom to it?

replies.author: shinunotenshi
replies.text: @Pytho-neista nice summary, thanks!

replies.author: Pytho-neista
replies.text:
There is no rule of thumb that you should have to use this much of layers and this activation function for this type of task. But there are somethings that need to be considered when training your network:
1.Your main goal is to prevent over-fitting, therefore you moniter metrics like accuracy and keep on changing the intermediate layers only. It should be kept in mind that neurons in a layers shouldn't be too much otherwise you will need large training data, or too less like in the order [784, 5, 10] as this will result in loss of information.
2. For intermediate layers ReLU works for most of the tasks, however "tanh" also works well.
3. For last layer the activation should be sigmoid if it is a binary classification problem (Your output neuron is 1). For multi-class classification, it should be softmax.
4. Loss function: for binary classification = binary_crossentropy, for classifying n-categories = categorical_crossentropy, for classifying n-categories but the output is one-hot encoded = sparse_categorical_crossentropy, or mean squared error for other tasks. 
5. Optimizer could be Adam or rmsprop, the both work fine and doesn't impact too much on accuracy.

replies.author: RoboticusMusic
replies.text: @abcd xxVery true. In the financial time series forecasting ML sphere I've only met one guy (Tom Starke) who has said anything rational. Everyone else is more or less Siraj. ML is not inherently bad but the industry is a huge elaborate scam like cryptocurrency. I haven't seen anyone build better ML models than the hand tuned hands-on real time manual adjustment algorithms I've built. I only need ML as icing on the cake to extract any last edge, and nobody seems to understand the basic principles of building a predictive model. For example none of the tutorials explain one-shot methods. That means everything out there overfits and it worse than useless! If a model can't learn in one episode it fundamentally is performing a very expensive database memorization hallucination.

replies.author: abcd xx

replies.author: RoboticusMusic
replies.text: Yep, or managing an automated 1D covnet with attention designed for time series prediction. This is both a desired topic at the moment and he could fundamentally demonstrate all the basics of building an automated pipeline where new data comes in, model updates and self optimizes, then outputs a prediction, process repeats upon completion or arrival of new data. This is something me and everyone getting into time series forecasting ML wants to see and it is not too ungodly complex like some other automated ML processes.
